of Assembly","icon":"ðŸ“¢","category":"Civil Rights","description":"What to know about your rights when participating in protests","phrases":["I am exercising my First Amendment rights.","Am I being detained or am I free to go?","I do not consent to a search.","I want to speak to a lawyer.","I am not interfering with police operations."],"rights":[{"title":"Right to Peaceful Assembly","description":"You have a fundamental right to gather with others to protest, march, and voice political viewpoints. This is protected as free speech. Peaceful assembly means no violence or property destruction. Police cannot prevent or disperse peaceful protesters without lawful justification (like blocking traffic).","source":"1st Amendment - Assembly and Petition; 14th Amendment","stateVariations":[]},{"title":"Right to Protest on Public Property","description":"You can protest on sidewalks, parks, public plazas, and other government property. These are traditional public forums for speech. However, authorities can enforce time, place, and manner restrictions if they apply equally to all groups and don't target your message. Permits may be required for large gatherings but cannot be denied based on viewpoint.","source":"1st Amendment; Public Forum Doctrine","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Strong protest protections; courts are skeptical of overly restrictive permit requirements"},{"state":"NY","note":"Robust assembly rights; NYC has strong tradition of protest; permit requirements are flexible"},{"state":"UT","note":"Requires permits for large gatherings in some cities; must apply viewpoint-neutral rules"},{"state":"TX","note":"Permits may be required; some restrictions on capital grounds; viewpoint neutrality required"},{"state":"FL","note":"Some anti-protest laws enacted (e.g., HB 1 in 2021 restricts blocking roadways)"}]},{"title":"Right to Photograph and Record in Public","description":"You can photograph and record video and audio of anything visible and audible from a public space. This includes police, protests, and government activities. You do not need permission. However, don't block others, trespass, or interfere with police work. Recording is important documentation of protests and police conduct.","source":"1st Amendment - Free Speech; Constitutional Right to Record Public Events","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Explicitly permits recording police and public events; strong protections"},{"state":"NY","note":"Court-affirmed right to record police and public events"},{"state":"TX","note":"Can record if you don't interfere; some ambiguity on audio recording"}]},{"title":"Rights if Arrested During a Protest","description":"If arrested at a protest, you still have full constitutional rights. You have the right to remain silentâ€”do not answer questions without a lawyer present. Request a lawyer immediately and clearly. Ask why you're being arrested. Do not resist, even if you believe the arrest is unlawful. Challenge it in court later with your lawyer.","source":"5th Amendment, 6th Amendment, Miranda Rights","stateVariations":[]},{"title":"Right to Free Speech","description":"The government cannot restrict your speech based on its viewpoint, message, or content. You can hold signs, chant, and speak about controversial topics. You cannot be arrested for offensive speech alone (with narrow exceptions like true threats). Your speech is protected even if others find it offensive or disagree strongly.","source":"1st Amendment - Free Speech Clause","stateVariations":[]}]},"availableStates":["CA","FL","NY","TX","UT"]}]}],"$L4"]}],null,"$L5"]}],"loading":null,"isPartial":false}
